factoid: The speaker invited listeners to come and visit and referred to a brave boy they had been together out there, playing the hero.
The speaker addressed Vasíli Ignátovich, saying, "How d’ye do, old fellow?" and turned to an old passing man.
Before the speaker finished his greeting, a footman announced that Bagratión had arrived.
Bells rang, stewards rushed forward, and guests scattered in different rooms came together and crowded in the large drawing room by the door of the ballroom.
Bagratión had given up his hat and sword to the hall porter in accord with the club custom.
Bagratión had no lambskin cap on his head.
Bagratión had no loaded whip over his shoulder.
Bagratión wore a tight new uniform with Russian and foreign orders and the Star of St. George on his left breast.
Just before coming to dinner, Bagratión had his hair and whiskers trimmed, changing his appearance for the worse.
Bagratión had a naïvely festive air.
Bagratión's firm and virile features gave him a rather comical expression.
Bekleshëv and Theodore Uvárov paused at the doorway to allow Bagratión to enter first as the guest of honor.
Bagratión was embarrassed and did not wish to avail himself of the courtesy of Bekleshëv and Theodore Uvárov, causing a delay at the doors.
Bagratión eventually entered first.
Bagratión walked shyly and awkwardly over the parquet floor of the reception room, not knowing what to do with his hands.
Bagratión was more accustomed to walk over a plowed field under fire, as he had done at the head of the Kursk regiment at Schön Grabern.
Bagratión would have found walking on the parquet easier than walking on a plowed field under fire.
Committee members met Bagratión at the first door, expressed delight at seeing him, took possession of him, surrounded him, and led him to the drawing room.
It was impossible to enter the drawing room door because a crowd of members and guests jostled, trying to get a good look at Bagratión.
Count Ilyá Rostóv pushed through the crowd, led guests into the drawing room, and seated them on the center sofa.
The bigwigs, the most respected members of the club, beset the new arrivals.
Count Ilyá went out of the drawing room, reappeared with a committee member, carrying a large silver salver, and presented it to Prince Bagratión.
On the salver lay verses composed and printed in honor of the hero.
Bagratión glanced around in dismay when he saw the salver.
All eyes demanded that Bagratión submit.
Bagratión took the salver with both hands and looked sternly and reproachfully at Count Ilyá.
Someone obligingly took the dish from Bagratión and drew his attention to the verses.
Bagratión said, "Well, I will read them, then," and began to read the verses with a fixed and serious expression.
The author took the verses and read them aloud.
Bagratión bowed his head and listened.
The verses read: Bring glory then to Alexander’s reign.
The verses read: And on the throne our Titus shield.
The verses read: A dreaded foe be thou, kindhearted as a man.
The verses read: A Rhipheus at home, a Caesar in the field!
The verses read: E’en fortunate Napoleon knows by experience, now, Bagratión.
The verses read: And dare not Herculean Russians trouble...
A stentorian major-domo announced that dinner was ready before Bagratión had finished reading.
The door opened and from the dining room came the resounding strains of the polonaise: Conquest’s joyful thunder waken, Triumph, valiant Russians, now.
